Term.Name: MPEG-1 Video
Term.Definition: MPEG-1 Video Coding Format. This part of ISO/IEC 11172 specifies a coded representation that can be used for compressing video sequences - both 625-line and 525-lines -to bitrates around 1,5 Mbit/s. It was developed to operate principally from storage media offering a continuous transfer rate of about 1,5 Mbit/s. Nevertheless it can be used more widely than this because the approach taken is generic
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML. First version date is version date from reference publisher

Term.Name: MPEG-2 Video
Term.Definition: MPEG-2 Video Coding Format. This Part of ISO/IEC 13818 was developed in response to the growing need for a generic coding method of moving pictures and of associated sound for various applications such as digital storage media, television broadcasting and communication. The use of this specification means that motion video can be manipulated as a form of computer data and can be stored on various storage media, transmitted and received over existing and future networks and distributed on existing and future broadcasting channels. MPEG-2 builds on the powerful video compression capabilities of the MPEG-1 standard to offer a wide range of coding tools. These have been grouped in profiles to offer different functionalities
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML. First version date is version date from reference publisher

Term.Name: JPEG
Term.Definition: Joint Pictures Expert Group. A standard for still image compression.Specifies processes for converting source image data to compressed image data, processes for converting compressed image data to reconstructed image data, coded representations for compressed image data, and gives guidance on how to implement these processes in practice. Is applicable to continuous-tone - grayscale or colour - digital still image data and to a wide range of applications which require use of compressed images. Is not applicable to bi-level image data
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML. First version date is version date from reference publisher

Term.Name: MJPEG
Term.Definition: Motion JPEG video coding. The digital video compression techniques which use JPEG coding applied to motion pictures. each video frame or interlaced field of a digital video sequence is separately compressed as a JPEG image.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML. First version date is version date from reference publisher

Term.Name: JPEG2000
Term.Definition: JPEG2000 Coding Format. The JPEG 2000 is intended to provide a new image coding system using state of the art compression techniques, based on the use of wavelet technology. Its architecture should lend itself to a wide range of uses from portable digital cameras through to its use in advanced pre-press, medical imaging and other key sectors
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML. First version date is version date from reference publisher

Term.Name: H261
Term.Definition: H261 Video Coding Format
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML. First version date is version date from reference publisher

Term.Name: H263
Term.Definition: H263 Video Coding Format, The video encoding standard, published by ITU, supporting video compression (coding) for video-conferencing and video-telephony applications. Typical bit rates are around 30 kbit/s
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML. First version date is version date from reference publisher

Term.Name: Analogue Black and White
Term.Definition: The analogue video signal is composed only by luminance
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML. First version date is version date from reference publisher

Term.Name: PAL
Term.Definition: Phase Alternating Line. The analogue colour coding system for television widely used in Europe and throughout the world, always almost with the 625/50 line/field system. Bandwith is typically 5.5 MHz luminance and 1.3 MHz for each of the colour difference signals. This composite coding system is used for transmission as well as for analogue television production
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML. First version date is version date from reference publisher

Term.Name: PAL-M
Term.Definition: Phase Alternating Line. This is PAL for the 525/60 line/field system case
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML. First version date is version date from reference publisher

Term.Name: NTSC
Term.Definition: The analogue colour television system, defined by the United States National Television Systems Committee, used in USA, Canada, Mexico and Japan, always almost with the 525/60 line/field system. It is a composite video standard. The bandwidth of the NTSC system is 4.2 MHz for the luminance signal and 1.3 and 0.4 MHz for the I and Q colur channels
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML. First version date is version date from reference publisher

Term.Name: SECAM
Term.Definition: Sequential Couleur Avec Mire. The analogue television broadcast standard used in France, the middle East, many African and Asian countries, and most of Eastern Europe. It is a composite colour transmission system, but it is not a production standard
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML. First version date is version date from reference publisher

Term.Name: Analogue RGB
Term.Definition: The analogue component video signal composed by the Red, Green and Blue signals, the primary colours of television
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML. First version date is version date from reference publisher

Term.Name: Analogue Y, (R-Y), (B-Y)
Term.Definition: The analogue component video signal composed by the luminance, Y, and colour difference signals (R-Y) and (B-Y)
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML. First version date is version date from reference publisher

Term.Name: Analogue Y, Cr, Cb
Term.Definition: The digital luminance and colour difference signals in ITU-R 601 coding. Always almost the Y luminance signal is sampled at 13.5 MHz and the two colour difference signals are sampled at 6.75 MHz co-sited with one of the luminace samples. Cr is the digitised version of the analogue component (R-Y), likewise Cb is the digitised version of (B-Y)
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML. First version date is version date from reference publisher

Term.Name: Sample Rate Reduction
Term.Definition: The digital picture is obtained either by a sampling from analogue video source at a resolution lower than the one specified by the relevant standard (e.g.ITU-R 601) or by any kind of down conversion from a higher resolution digital picture. In both cases there is a reduction of the total number of pixels, that may be obtained by reducing the number of pixels per line, or the number of lines per picture, or the number of picture per second
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML. First version date is version date from reference publisher

Term.Name: DV
Term.Definition: The digital video compression technique adopted by DV camcorders and DVTRs, based on DCT compression, and especially suitable for fixed bitrate coding such as for tape recording. The original standard document was known as Blue Book. Current standard is IEC 61834
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML. First version date is version date from reference publisher

Term.Name: RealVideo
Term.Definition: Proprietary video format developed by RealNetworks. This format uses compression techniques that reduce the frame rate of the video clip and routines that remove unnecessary information within frames. The quality can vary greatly depending on the amount of motion and detail in the original video.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML. First version date is version date from reference publisher

Term.Name: Dirac
Term.Definition: Open Source Codec from BBC, Using wavelets, it compresses any size of picture from low-resolution QCIF (176x144 pixels) to HDTV (1920x1080) and beyond.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML. First version date is version date from reference publisher

Term.Name: DivX
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML. First version date is version date from reference publisher

Term.Name: Windows Media Video
Term.Definition: Video codec technologies developed by Microsoft for its Windows Media Player.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML. First version date is version date from reference publisher
